div.stage: ALICE, a beautiful woman with her back to CAMERA, lets drop an elegant black dress to the floor.
BILL and ALICE's apartment block on Central Park West.

A handsome man in evening dress is looking for something. He walks into a bedroom, goes to a small table, picks up keys and a mobile phone and walks to a chest of drawers. This is Bill Harford, a doctor.
Bill opens a drawer and takes out a handkerchief

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Honey, have you seen my wallet?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Ah ... isn't it on the bedside table?

div.stage: BILL walks across to the bedside table and finds his wallet.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Ah, yep ... now listen, you know we're running a little late?

div.stage: BILL goes around the bed and into the en-suite bathroom. ALICE is sitting on the loo wearing an evening dress.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I know. How do I look?

div.stage: BILL goes to the mirror to check his appearance without looking at ALICE.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Perfect.

div.stage: ALICE gets up from the loo as BILL checks his bow tie.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Is my hair OK?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's great.

div.stage: ALICE drops the toilet tissue in the loo and flushes it
away. ALICE You're not even looking at it. BILL turns and looks at her adoringly.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's beautiful.

div.stage: BILL kisses her affectionately on the cheek and leaves the bathroom.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You always look beautiful.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Did you give Roz the phone and pager numbers?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yeah. I put it on the fridge ... let's go, huh?

div.stage: ALICE washes her hands and dries them as she looks in the mirror.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Good. All right, I'm ready.

div.stage: ALICE removes her glasses, leaves the bathroom and goes to the bed to pick up her coat and bag. BILL, his overcoat on his arm, switches off the music centre. They leave the bedroom together. BILL switches off the lights.
BILL and ALICE walk down the corridor. ALICE starts to put her coat on and BILL helps her.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What's the name of the baby sitter?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Roz.

div.stage: They enter a spacious and comfortably furnished living room where HELENA, their seven-year-old daughter, sits watching television with ROZ, the student baby sitter. There is a decorated Christmas tree behind the sofa.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: OK, Roz. We're going now.

sp.speaker: ROZ
sp.p: Wow! You look amazing, Mrs Harford!

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, thank you ... Helena, are you ready for bed?

div.stage: BILL puts on his overcoat.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Yes, mummy. Can I stay up and watch The Nutcracker?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: What time's it on?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Nine o'clock.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Sure, you can watch that.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Can I stay up until you get home?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: No, darling.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's going to be a little late for that.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Now, the phone number is on the fridge . . ..

div.stage: ALICE bends down to kiss HELENA.

sp.speaker: ROZ
sp.p: OK.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: And there's plenty of food in there, so help yourself.

sp.speaker: ROZ
sp.p: OK.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: We shouldn't be home any later than one o'clock.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'll hold our cab tonight to take you home.

sp.speaker: ROZ
sp.p: Thanks, Dr Harford.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You be a good baby.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Good night, mummy. Good night, daddy. Goodbye . . . bye.

sp.speaker: ROZ
sp.p: Have fun.

div.stage: BILL and ALICE leave, blowing kisses and waving bye-bye to HELENA.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: See you in the morning.

div.stage: BILL and ALICE walk down the apartment corridor.
A palatial house in mid-town Manhattan. Doormen stand outside the entrance. A large stretch limo is parked nearby.

BILL and ALICE, holding hands, walk down a corridor lined with display cases and works of art. A large party is in progress. Guests, all in evening wear, are still arriving. An orchestra playing dance music can be heard further off in the house.
BILL and ALICE come into a large hallway where their hosts, Victor ZIEGLER and his wife, ILONA, are greeting the guests to their annual Christmas party.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Victor, Ilona....

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Bill, Alice....

div.stage: The hall is large and marbled with a vast staircase in the background. Illuminations creating a "curtain of light" hang from the walls and there is a Christmas tree laden with decorations. ZIEGLER, afit, sun-tanned man in his fifties, and his beautiful wife welcome BILL and ALICE.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Merry Christmas!

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Merry Christmas! How good to see both of you. Thanks so much for coming.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: We wouldn't have missed it for the world.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Alice, look at you! God, you're absolutely stunning.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, thank you.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: And I don't say that to all the women, do I?

sp.speaker: ILONA
sp.p: Oh, yes, he does.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: He does!

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Hey, that osteopath you sent me to got to work on my arm ... you should see my serve now, it's terrific!

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: He's the top man in New York.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: I could have told you that looking at his bill. Listen, go inside, have a drink, enjoy the party and I'll see you in a little bit. OK? Thanks for coming.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Bye.

div.stage: BILL and ALICE make their way to the crowded main reception room.

The walls are draped with the "curtain of light" illuminations seen in the corridor. There is a stage and upon it is the small orchestra playi,ng ballroom music. The guests dance on the crowded floor. BILL and ALICE dance together.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Do you know anyone here?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Not a soul.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Why do you think Ziegler invites us to these things every year?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: This is what you get for making house calls. On the stage there is a young man of similar age to BILL playing the piano. He is dressed in a white tux and bow tie. He looks around. This is NICK Nightingale. BILL notices him.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You see that guy at the piano? I went to medical school with him.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Really? He plays pretty good for a doctor.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: He's not a doctor. He dropped out.

div.stage: The bandleader brings the music to a stop.

sp.speaker: BANDLEADER
sp.p: Ladies and gentlemen, I hope you're enjoying yourselves. The band is going to take a short break now and we'll be back in ten minutes.

div.stage: The guests applaud as the band leaves the stage.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Let's go over and say hello to him.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Honey, I desperately need to go to the bathroom. You go and say hello and I'll meet you ... where? At the bar?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good.

div.stage: BILL kisses ALICE on the cheek as she leaves the ballroom.
Crowded with guests. ALICE walks by a waiter holding a tray with glasses of champagne. She takes a glass without stopping and drinks it "in one" as she moves away.
On stage, by the piano, Nick Nightingale sorts through some sheet music as the band takes its break. Bill walks up to the stage.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nightingale! Nick Nightingale!

div.stage: NICK looks around to see who is calling his name. He jumps down from the stage and he and BILL greet each other like old fri,ends.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Oh, my God! Bill! Bill Harford! How the hell are you,buddy?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How long has it been?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Oh, jeez! I don't know, about ten years?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And a couple. Do you have time for a drink?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Sure.

div.stage: BILL puts his arm round NICK's shoulders as they walk to the other end of the ballroom.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: God, you haven't changed a bitl

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Thanks, I think. So how you doing?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Not too bad, you know, not too bad. I see you've become a pianist.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Oh, yes. Well my friends call me that. How about you? You still in the doctor business?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You know what they say, once a doctor always a doctor.

div.stage: BILL takes a couple of glasses of champagne from a waiter standing with a tray and hands one to NICK.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Yes, or in my case, never a doctor, never a doctor.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I never did understand why you walked away.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: No? It's a nice feeling. I do it a lot. Cheers.

div.stage: They "clink" glasses as a man in evening dress walks up to NICK. This is ZIEGLER's SECRETARY.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: Excuse me ... Nick, I need you a minute.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Be right with you.
Listen, I gotta go do something. If I don't catch you later, I'm gonna be down the Village for two weeks in a place called the Sonata cafe. Stop by if you get a chance.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'll be there. Great seeing you.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Good seeing you too.

div.stage: They exchange friendly pats as Nick goes.

ALICE stands, back to the bar, holding a glass of champagne. The room is crowded with people talking. A tall, handsome man, suave and middle-aged, also stands at the bar. He turns from a conversation he is having and notices ALICE next to him. His name is Sandor SZAVOST. He takes a sip of whisky as he studies her, and puts his glass down on the bar. ALICE, still looking for BILL to join her, also puts her champagne glass down. SZAVOST then nonchalantly picks ALICE's glass up as ALICE turns to do the same.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Umm, I ... I think that's my glass.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: I'm absolutely certain of it.

div.stage: SZAVOST stares into ALICE's eyes as he seductively drinks the contents of ALICE's glass.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: My name is Sandor Szavost. I'm Hungarian.

div.stage: He takes Alice's hand and kisses it.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: My name is Alice Harford. I'm American.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: Delighted to meet you, Alice. Did you ever read the Latin poet Ovid on The Art of Love?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Didn't he wind up all by himself? Crying his eyes out in some place with a very bad climate?

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: But he also had a good time first, a very good time. Are you here with anyone tonight, Alice?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: With my husband.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: Oh, how sad! But then I'm sure he's the sort of man who wouldn't mind if we danced.

div.stage: ALICE thinks for a moment then offers her arm to SZAVOST.
SZAVOST and ALICE dance closely on the crowded floor.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: What do you do, Alice?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Well, at the moment I am looking for a job. I used to manage an art gallery in Soho but it went broke.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: Oh, what a shame! I have some friends in the art game. Perhaps they can be of some help?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, thank you.

div.stage: As they turn, ALICE catches sight of BILL talking to two beautiful girls in the ante-room beyond.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: Someone you know?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: My husband.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: Oh. Don't you think one of the charms of marriage is that it makes deception a necessity for both parties? ALICE laughs.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: May I ask why a beautiful women who could have any man in this room wants to be married?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Why wouldn't she?

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: Is it as bad as that?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: As good as that.

div.stage: The two beautiful girls, GAYLE and NUALA, have their arms draped around each other as they talk to BILL.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: Do you know Nuala Windsor?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, no. And it's very, very lovely to meet you both.

div.stage: They all laugh.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How do you spell Nuala?

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: You don't remember me, do you?

div.stage: BILL tries to think.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: You were very kind to me once.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Only once? That sounds like a terrible oversight!

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: I was doing a photo session in Rockefeller Plaza, on a very windy day.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And you got something in your eye?

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: Just about half of Fifth Avenue.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: You were such a gentleman, you gave me your handkerchief, which was also clean.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well that is the kind of hero I can be ... sometimes.

div.stage: ALICE and SZAVOST continue dancing.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: You know why women used to get married, don't you?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Why don't you tell me?

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: It was the only way they could lose their virginity and be free to do what they wanted with other men ... the ones they really wanted.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Fascinating.

div.stage: GAYLE and NUALA walk on each side of BILL, their arms linked through his.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: Do you know what's so nice about doct or-.,

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Usually a lot less than people imagi ne.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: They always seem so knowledgeable.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh, they are very knowledgeable about all sort of things.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: But I bet they work too hard. Just think of all they miss.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You're probably right. Now. where exactly are we going . . . exactly?

div.stage: They come into a large room where there are few people.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: Where the rainbow ends?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Where the rainbow ends? They come to a stop.

sp.speaker: NUALA
sp.p: Don't you want to go where the rainbow ends?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, now that depends where that is.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: Well, let's find out.

div.stage: A tall good looking man walks up to them and interrupts. He is HARRIS, ZIEGLER's personal assistant.

sp.speaker: HARRIS
sp.p: Excuse me, ladies.
Sorry, Dr Halford. Sorry to interrupt. I wonder whether you could come with me for a moment? Something for Mr Ziegler.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh ... umm ... Fine.
To be continued?

div.stage: HARRIS leads BILL across the hall and up the marble staircase.

ZIEGLER hurriedly pulls his trousers up while looking down on a girl lying unconscious and naked in an armchair. This is MANDY who is making quiet muttering noises. ZIEGLER is panic stricken. He hears a knock on the door and runs barefoot across the bathroom to open it.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Yeah?

div.stage: He opens the door to see BILL standing there with HARRIS. He shakes BILL's hand.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Bill, thank God.

div.stage: ZIEGLER closes the door, leaving HARRIS outside to keep watch.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: We had a ... had a little accident here. They walk over to MANDY.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What happened?

div.stage: BILL takes a closer look at MANDY.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Well, she ... she was shooting up and she ... she had a bad reaction.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What did she take?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Speedhall or snowball or whatever the hell they call it. You know, it's ... it's heroin and coke.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Heroin and coke ... uh-huh. Anything else?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Ah, yeah, a couple of drinks. Nothing really. Some champagne. That was it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How long's she been like this?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Maybe five minutes, six minutes. Something like that.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What's her name?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Mandy ... Mandy.

div.stage: MANDY continues making quiet, muttering noises.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Mandy. Mandy. Can you hear me, Mandy? Can you hear me? Just move your head for me if you can hear me. Just move your head for me if you can hear me, Mandy. There you go, you can hear me. Can you open your eyes for me? Mandy? Can you do that? Let me see you do that. Let me see you open your eyes. There you go. Come on, come on. Look at me, look at me, look at me, look at me. Look at me. Look at me, Mandy. Good. Good.

div.stage: SZAVOST and ALICE are still dancing. ALICE is quite intoxi,cated by both SZAVOSTand the champagne.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: I love Victor's art collection, don't you?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes ... it's wonderful.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: Have you ever seen his sculpture gallery?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: No, I haven't.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: He has a wonderful collection of Renaissance bronzes. Do you like the period?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Hmm ... I do.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: I adore it. The sculpture gallery is upstairs. Would you like to see it? I can show it to you. We won't be gone long.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Maybe ... not just ... now.

div.stage: ZIEGLER, now dressed in his shirt, does his cufflinks up.
BILL leans up against a sideboard, anns folded, watching At.ANDY. She is still in the chair, but she is now covered with a blue bathrobe. ZIEGLER stands over her.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Well, that was really one hell of a scare you gave us, kiddo.

sp.speaker: MANDY
sp.p: Sorry.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How are you feeling now, Mandy?

sp.speaker: MANDY
sp.p: Better.

div.stage: BILL goes over to her and kneels down.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You are a very, very lucky girl. You know that?

sp.speaker: MANDY
sp.p: I know.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You're going to be OK this time, but you can't keep doing this. You understand?

sp.speaker: MANDY
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You're going to need some rehab. You know that, don't you?

sp.speaker: MANDY
sp.p: I know.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: OK ... OK.

div.stage: BILL gets up and turns to ZIEGLER.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, Victor, I think I can leave the rest to you.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Is it OK if I get some clothes on her and get her out of here?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No. I'd ... I'd keep her here for another hour.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Another hour?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'd have someone take her home.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: OK ... OK.

div.stage: They walk towards the door.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Goodnight, Mandy.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Listen, I can't thank you enough for this. You saved my ass.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm glad I was here.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Bill ... I probably ... I know I don't have to mention this, but this is just between us. OK?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Of course.

div.stage: ALICE, eyes shut, dances closely to SZAVOST, as if in a trance. She brings herself "to" as they stop dancing. ALICE
I think I've had a little too much champagne. I think I have to go and find my husband now.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: I'm sure he'll be all right on his own a little longer.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes, but will I?

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: Of course you will.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: No, no, no, I ... I really have to go. I have to go.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: You don't, you know.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: Alice, I must see you again.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: That's impossible.

sp.speaker: SZAVOST
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Because ... I'm married.

div.stage: ALICE waves her ring finger in front of SZAVOST's face. She kisses her index finger and plants it on SZAVOST's lips as she leaves him on the dance floor.

ALICE stands naked in front of the bedroom mirror. She removes an ear-ring as she sways around. As she begins to take the other ear-ring off BILL comes up behind her and starts to caress her. He puts his arms around her and lovingly touches her. She responds to his caresses by taking her glasses off and putting her arms around him. They kiss. ALICE looks at herself in the mirror as BILL kisses her neck and shoulder.
The lift doors open and BILL steps out.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good morning, Lisa.

sp.speaker: LISA
sp.p: Good morning, doctor. Your mail.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good. Please ask Janelle if she will bring me my

div.stage: coffee. LISA
Sure.
BILL walks through the reception towards his office. BILL
Thank you. Good morning, Sarah.

sp.speaker: SARAH
sp.p: Good morning, doctor.

div.stage: ALICE sits reading the morning paper and drinking her coffee dressed in a morning gown. HELENA, still in her night clothes, eats breakfast while watching television.
BILL examines a young woman's chest using a stethoscope. His female nurse stands by as an observer.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: OK. That's fine. You can put your gown on.

div.stage: HELENA, in a red dress and jumper, is havi,ng her hair brushed by ALICE, still in her morning gown.
ALICE then gives HELENA the brush.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Hold....

div.stage: HELENA takes the brush as ALICE arranges her daughter's hair in a pony tail.
BILL examines a young boy's neck glands as his mother waits in the background.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Looking forward to Christmas?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Does this hurt?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Yeah.

div.stage: ALICE is naked. She puts on a bra.
BILL, with female nurse in attendance, examines a man who lies on the table. He pulls the patient's leg gently upwards.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Right there?

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Yeah.

div.stage: ALICE, in skirt and bra, rolls deodorant under her arms as HELENA cleans her teeth.
ALICE and HELENA wrap Christmas presents on the table.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, daddy's gonna like that ... a very good choice.

div.stage: BILL and ALICE sit with HELENA as she reads from her picture book, ALICE prompting her as BILL watches and listens.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Before me, when I jump into my bed.

div.stage: ALICE walks by the dining table as she goes to the sitting room. She yawns as she goes.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I should call the Zieglers and thank them for the party last night.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I've taken care of that.

div.stage: BILL sits on the sofa watching a football game on television. ALICE joins him.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: So how do you feel about wrapping the rest of the presents?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh, oh ... let's do that tomorrow.

div.stage: ALICE, tired, looks into the mirror of the bathroom cabinet. She opens it up and takes out a Band-Aid tin. She opens the tin and removes a packet of cigarette papers and a polythene bag ofgrass (marijuana). She leaves the bathroom.
ALICE rolls a joint.
ALICE, lying on the bed in her underwear, takes a "pull" on the joint. She passes the spliff to BILL, who sits on the bed next to her dressed only in boxer shorts.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Hmm ... tell me something ... those two girls at the party last night. Did you, by any chance, happen to fuck them?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What!? What are you talking about!?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I'm talking about the two girls that you were so blatantly hitting on.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I wasn't hitting on anybody.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Hmm ... Who were they?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: They were just a couple of models.

div.stage: ALICE sits up next to BILL.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: And where did you disappear to with them for so long?

div.stage: BILL starts to kiss and touch ALICE.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Ohhhh! Wait a minute, wait a minute! I didn't disappear with anybody. Ziegler wasn't feeling too well. I got called upstairs to see him. Anyway, who's the guy you were dancing with?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: A friend of the Zieglers'.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What did he want?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: What did he want? Oh ... what did he want? Sex - upstairs, then and there.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yeah ... yeah. That was all.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Just wanted to fuck my wife.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yeah, that's right.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I guess that's understandable.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Understandable?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Because you are a very, very beautiful woman.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Woah! Woah! Woah! Wait!

div.stage: ALICE puts the spliff into the ashtray on the bed, disengages herself from BILL's arms, and gets up. She backs up towards the bathroom leaving BILL sitting on the bed.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: So ... because I'm a beautiful woman the only reason any man wants to talk to me is because he wants to fuck me! Is that what you're saying?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, I don't think it's quite that black and white, but I think we both know what men are like.

div.stage: ALICE now leans against the door frame.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: So, on that basis I should conclude that you wanted to fuck those two models?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: There are exceptions.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: What makes you an exception?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What makes me an exception is that . .. I happen to be in love with you and because we're married and because I would never lie to you or hurt you.

div.stage: ALICE starts walking to the other end of the room.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Do you realize that what you're saying is that the only reason you wouldn't fuck those two models is out of consideration for me, not because you really wouldn't want to?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Let's just relax, Alice. This pot is making you aggressive.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: No, it's not the pot, it's you! Why can't you ever give me a straight fucking answer!

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I was under the impression that's what I was doing. I don't even know what we're arguing about here.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I'm not arguing. I'm just trying to find out where you're coming from.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Where I'm coming from?

div.stage: ALICE gets up and stands at the end of the bed. ALICE

Let's say, let's say for example, you have some gorgeous woman standing in your office naked and you're feeling her fucking tits. Now, what I wanna know ... I wanna know what are you really thinking about when you're squeezing them?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Alice, I happen to be a doctor. It's all very impersonal and you know there is always a nurse present.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: So, when you are feeling tits it's nothing more than your professionalism, is that what you're saying?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Exactly ... sex is the last thing on my mind when I'm with a patient.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Now, when she is having her little titties squeezed, do you think she ever has any little fantasies about what handsome Doctor Bill's dickie might be like?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Come on, I can assure you that sex is the last thing on this fucking hypothetical woman patient's mind.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: And what makes you so sure?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: If for no better reason ... because she's afraid of what I might find.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: OK! OK! So, so, so after you tell her that everything's fine, what then?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What then? Ah, I don't know that, Alice. What then? Look, women don't ... they basically don't think like that.

div.stage: ALICE gets up and provocatively points a finger at BILL as she starts to pace up and down at the foot of the bed.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Millions of years of evolution, right? Right? Men have to stick it in every place they can, but for women ... women it is just about security and commitment and whatever the fuck ... else!

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: A little oversimplified, Alice, but yes, something like that.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: If you men only knew....

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'll tell you what I do know is that you got a little stoned tonight. You've been trying to pick a fight with me and now you're trying to make me jealous.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: But you're not the jealous type, are you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, I'm not.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You've never been jealous about me, have you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, I haven't.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: And why haven't you ever been jealous about me?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, I don't know, Alice. Maybe because you're my wife, maybe because you're the mother of my child and I know you would never be unfaithful to me.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You are very, very sure of yourself, aren't you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, I'm sure of you.

div.stage: ALICE bursts out laughing.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Do you think that's funny?

div.stage: ALICE collapses onto the floor, her laughing fit uncontrollable now.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fucking laughing fit, right?

div.stage: ALICE calms down a little.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Do you ... do you remember last summer at Cape Cod?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Do you remember one night in the dining room? There was this young naval officer and he was sitting near our table with two other officers?

div.stage: ALICE sits back against the radiator and focuses on her story.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: The waiter brought him a message at which point he left. Nothing rings a bell?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Well, I first saw him that morning in the lobby. He was ... he was checking into the hotel and he was following the bell-boy with his luggage, to the elevator. He ... he glanced at me as he walked past, just a glance. Nothing more. But I could hardly move. That afternoon Helena went to the movies with her friend and you and I made love, and we made plans about our future and we talked about Helena and yet at no time was he ever out of my mind. And I thought if he wanted me, even if it was for only one night, I was ready to give up everything. You, Helena, my whole fucking future. Everything. And yet it was weird because at the same time you were dearer to me than ever and ... and at that moment my love for you was both tender and sad. I ... I barely slept that night and I woke up the next morning in a panic. I didn't know whether I was afraid he had left or that he might still be there, but by dinner I realized he was gone and I was relieved.

div.stage: BILL is stunned by what ALICE is telling him and it is some time before he can respond to the repeated ringing of the telephone. He finally picks it up.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hello? Yes, this is Dr Harford. When did it happen? No, no, erh ... I have the address. Thank you.
Lou Nathansonjust died. I'm gonna have to go over there and show my face.

div.stage: BILL sits in the cab thinking about what ALICE has told him.
BILL, in his jealousy, fantasises about ALICE and the NAVAL OFFICER making love.
BILL continues to torture himself with ALICE's confession.
The elevator door opens and BILL comes out. He walks across the elegant, art deco lobby and presses a doorbell.
A maid walks to the door of the luxurious apartment and peeps through the spy-hole. This is ROSA. She opens the door.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good evening, Rosa.

sp.speaker: ROSA
sp.p: Good evening, Dr Harford.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How is Miss Nathanson?

sp.speaker: ROSA
sp.p: Not so good. She's in the bedroom.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thank you.

div.stage: BILL walks down the hallway, passing numerous objets d'art and paintings and comes to a door. He knocks.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Come in.

div.stage: BILL goes into the room.
BILL comes into the bedroom and is greeted by a beautiful woman in her late thirties. This is MARION Nathanson who is crying over the loss of her father.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh! Dr Harford! How . . . how good of you to come.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I came as soon as I got the message.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh, thank you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm so ... I'm so sorry.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh, thank you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Your father was a ... was a very brave man.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh, thank you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How are you holding up?

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Ah ... ah ... I'm a bit numb. I don't think it's really sunk in yet. Erh, would you like to sit down?

div.stage: BILL walks around the bed and up to the dead body of LOU NATHANSON. BILL puts his hand on the corpse's forehead and then he and MARION move to a table and chairs nearby and sit down.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: It's so unreal. Daddy had such a good day. His mind was clear and he remembered so many things and then he had a little dinner and he said he felt like taking a nap. I ... I went into the kitchen and talked to Rosa for half an hour at most and when I went back in to see how he was I just thought he was asleep and then I ... then I realized he wasn't breathing.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion, from what you've said, I'm sure your father died peacefully in his sleep.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh, God! I hope so! I think I've been more afraid of the way it was actually going to happen than his death itself.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Have you had a chance to phone any of your relatives?

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I umm ... I tried to call my step-mother in London but, erh, she was out. My boyfriend, Carl, is making some calls and umm, he'll be coming over soon. I think you've met Carl here a few times?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, I remember him. He's a teacher isn't he?

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: A maths professor. We're going to get married in May.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, that's wonderful news. Congratulations.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Thank you. Carl has a new teaching appointment at the University of Michigan. We'll be moving out there soon.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, Michigan is a beautiful state. I think you'll like it a lot.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It really could be a wonderful change for you, Marion.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I ... oh! No. I ... Oh, my God! No! I ... I love you. I love you. I love you. I love you.

div.stage: MARION tries to control herself, but she finally breaks down. She looks at BILL in desperation then moves forward to kiss him passionately on his lips.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I love you. I don't want to go away with Carl.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion, I don't think you realize ....

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I do, even if I'm never to see you again, I want at least to live near you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion, listen to me, listen to me. You're very upset right now and I don't think you realize what you're saying.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I love you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: We barely know each other. I don't think we've had a single conversation about anything except your father.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I love you. The sound of the door chimes is heard.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh, that's probably Carl. Please don't despise me.

div.stage: She gets up, leaving BILL to sit and ponder what has happened.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Hello, Rosa.

sp.speaker: ROSA
sp.p: Hello, Mr Thomas.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Is she ... is she in the bedroom?

sp.speaker: ROSA
sp.p: Yes, she is.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Thank you.

div.stage: CARL walks down the corridor and comes to the bedroom door. He knocks.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Come in.

div.stage: CARL enters and walks across to MARION. They kiss.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Darling, I'm so very sorry. Are you all right?

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I'm OK.

div.stage: CARL walks over to BILL and they shake hands.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Dr Harford, good evening.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good evening, Carl.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Thank you very much for coming over here tonight.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's the least I could do.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: It means a lot to us.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thank you.
Well, I, I was actually on my way out.
Marion, your father was very proud of you and I know you gave him great comfort these last months.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well....

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Well ... I'll show you out.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good night.

div.stage: CARL shows BILL out and MARION is left in a state of confusion.
Cabs, night life, a few pedestrians.
BILL walks aimlessly along the street. He sees a young couple up against a shop front kissing passionately, oblivious of all around them.
The taunting fantasy image ofALICE and the NAVAL OFFICER making love returns to haunt BILL.
BILL continues walking, beating his fists in anger over his fantasy. He turns a comer and sees a gang of rowdy college boys coming towards him. The six of them take up the whole sidewalk.

sp.speaker: STUDENT I
sp.p: I'm serious, I got scars on the back of my neck.

div.stage: They notice BILL and start to hurl insults at him.

sp.speaker: STUDENT 2
sp.p: Hey! Hey! Hey! Hey! What team's this we're trying to play for?

sp.speaker: STUDENT I
sp.p: Looks like the pink team!

div.stage: BILL moves aside to avoid them, but as they pass, one of them deliberately elbows him up against a car parked by the sidewalk. BILL falls but regains his balance. The students start to insult him, provocatively taunting him about his sexuality. BILL stands and angrily stares at them then, as they continue down the street shouting their insults, he finally turns and walks on.

BILL continues on his way, hands deep in pockets, mind deep in thought. He comes to a street crossing where he has to wait before continuing. He is approached by a young girl, dressed in a fun-fur coat and hat. This is DOMINO.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Excuse me, do you know what time it is?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Ten past twelve.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Going anywhere special?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, I'm just ... just taking a walk.

div.stage: He starts to cross the street and the girl falls in step alongside him.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: How'd you like to have a little fun?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm . . . I'm sorry?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: A little fun? I just live right down there.

div.stage: She indicates a house farther down the street.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Would you like to come inside with me?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Come inside with you?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Yeah. It's a lot nicer in there than it is out here. They slow to a stop and BILL furtively looks around.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You ... you live in there?

div.stage: He sees the apartment building, its front door painted bright red.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: By yourself?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: No. I have a room-mate but she's not home. Hey, it's OK. Listen, no-one will bother us. It's OK. Come on. Come on....

div.stage: DOMINO gently pulls him up the stoop to the front door.
DOMINO leads BILL across the small, dingy lobby to a door on the ground floor. She unlocks the door and they enter.
DOMINO comes in and BILL follows, looking around as he does. He notices a decorated Christmas tree in the hallway.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: This is it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: A nice tree.

div.stage: DOMINO laughs and leads him into a very messy kitchen.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Oh, sorry about the mess. Maid's day off.

div.stage: BILL looks around then sits awkwardly on the edge of the bath tub.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's a ... it's a ... cosy, cosy place.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: It's OK.

div.stage: There is an embarrassed silence as DOMINO takes off her hat and coat.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: So, do you, do you suppose we should talk about money?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Yeah, I guess so. It depends on what you want to do. What do you wanna do?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, what do you recommend?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: What do I recommend? Umm ... well ... I ... I'd rather not put it into words. How about you just leave it up to me?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm in your hands.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: OK ... and how does a hundred and fifty sound?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sounds ... wonderful.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Don't worry, I don't keep track of the time.

div.stage: ALICE sits eating cookies and smoking a cigarette while watching television. She is dressed in her blue silk dress. zng gown.
DOMINO and BILL sit on the bed, faces close together. Very slowly DOMINO leans forward and gently kisses BILL on the lips. BILL, uncertain at first, responds a little.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: So, shall we?

div.stage: BILL's mobile phone rings. Hesitating for a moment, he finally gets off the bed and walks across to the stereo music centre and switches it off. He turns to DOMINO and puts his finger to his lips so DOMINO will keep quiet.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Excuse me ...

div.stage: BILL faces the wall away from DOMINO as he takes the call.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hello?

div.stage: ALICE is on the telephone.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hi. Is everything all right?

div.stage: Yeah ... I was, I was just wondering if you were going to be much longer?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Umm .. . listen, it's .. . it's a little difficult to talk right now. It could be a while.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Any idea how long?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, I don't really know. We're still waiting for some relatives to arrive.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Well, I'm ... I'm gonna go to bed now.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: OK. Bye-bye.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Bye.

div.stage: DOMINO is now leaning back on the bed.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Was that Mrs Dr Bill?

div.stage: BILL, embarrassed, walks back towards the bed.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes ... yes.

div.stage: He sits down next to DOMINO again.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Do you have to go?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I have to go. I think I do.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Are you sure?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, I'm afraid so. Ah, but listen, I want to pay you anyway.

div.stage: BILL takes his wallet out of his inside jacket pocket.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How much did you say it was? Hundred and fifty?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Yeah, but you know what? You don't have to bother about that.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, it's all right.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: No, really, you don't have to.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, I want to.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Really?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Really.

div.stage: BILL takes DOMINO's hand and presses the bills in it.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Well, thank you very much.

div.stage: BILL walks down a street and happens by the Cafe Sonata where NICK Nightingale mentioned he was playing. BILL stops and looks in the window where he sees a photograph of NICK sitting at the piano. BILL thinks for a moment then makes for the door, which is opened by a doorman.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thank you.

div.stage: BILL walks down the stairs of the club. We hear live music as BILL is greeted by the MAITRE D'.

sp.speaker: MAITRE D'
sp.p: Good evening, sir. Would you like a table or would you like to sit at the bar?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'd like a table.

sp.speaker: MAITRE D'
sp.p: Please, follow me. Can I take your coat?

div.stage: As BILL is taken to his table we see his fri,end, NICK,
playing piano on stage with a jazz trio.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MAITRE D'
sp.p: Can I get you anything to drink?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'd like a beer.

sp.speaker: MAITRE D'
sp.p: Certainly.

div.stage: BILL watches the group as it finishes its final number. Then NICK quickly gets the band into the fast closing theme to cover his introductions to the musicians and his thanks to the audience.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Hope you enjoyed the music tonight. We're going to be here for the next two weeks. So, please, do stop by. I'm Nick Nightingale. Good night.

div.stage: NICK leaves the stage and walks through the club.

sp.speaker: VOICE FROM AUDIENCE
sp.p: Nick, that was great!

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Oh, thanks.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nightingale!

div.stage: NICK sees BILL and goes over to him.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Hey, Bill! You made it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yeah, listen, I'm sorry. I got here just as you were finishing your last set.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: That's all right, the band sucked tonight anyway.

div.stage: The MAITRE D' brings BILL his beer.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What are you drinking?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: A vodka and tonic, please.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: So what brings you out at this hour?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I have a patient in the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Do you live in the Village?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, we have an apartment on Central Park West.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Are you married?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nine years.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Do you have any kids?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, we have a seven-year-old daughter. How about you?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: I've got a wife and four boys in Seattle.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You're a long way from home.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Yeah, well, you've gotta go where the work is.

div.stage: The MAITRE D' brings NICK his drink.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Thank you.

div.stage: They touch glasses then drink.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: So, is this your band?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: No, this is just a pick-up band.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Who do you normally play with?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Anybody, anywhere. As a matter of fact I got another gig later tonight.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You're playing somewhere else tonight? NICK

div.stage: Mmm.... they only get started there around two.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: In the Village?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Believe it or not, I don't actually know the address yet.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You don't?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: No. It may sound ridiculous, but it's in a clifferent place every time and I only get it an hour or so before.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Different place every time?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: So far.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What's the big mystery?

div.stage: NICK dangles his hands in front of BILL'sface.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Hey, man! I just play the piano.

div.stage: They start to giggle nervously.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick, I'm sorry. Is there something I'm missing here?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: I play blindfolded.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Yeah, I play blindfolded.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You're putting me on?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: No, it's the truth. And the last time, the blindfold wasn't on so well ... man ... Bill, I have seen one or two things in my life but never, never anything like this ... and never such women.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well?

div.stage: NICK's mobile phone rings. He takes it out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Excuse me.
Hello? Yes, sir. Yes, sir. This is Nick. Uh-huh, I know where that is.

div.stage: NICK takes a pen from his pocket and starts to write on a paper napkin. He finds it difficult so BILL reaches across and holds the napkin. NICK writes on it the word "FIDELIO"

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Uh-huh .. .. right. OK. Well, I'm on my way right now. OK, sir. Thank you. Bye-bye.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What is this?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: It's the name of a Beethoven opera, isn't it?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick....

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: It's the password.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: The password?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Yeah, like I'm ... I'm really sorry to do this to you, Bill. I mean, I ... I gotta get going. I gotta ... I gotta go.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick, you know there is no way on earth that you are going to leave here tonight without taking me with you.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Come on, buddy, give me a break.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick, I'll tell you what. I've already got the password. Just give me the address and I'll go there by myself and there won't be any connection between us whatsoever.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Listen, let's just say for one second that I was prepared to do that. You couldn't get in anyway in those clothes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Because everyone is always costumed and masked, and where the hell are you gonna get a costume at this hour of the morning?

div.stage: A taxi turns the comer and pulls up outside a costume shop named RAINBOW FASHIONS. BILL gets out of the cab and pays the driver.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thanks. Keep the change.

div.stage: BILL walks up the stoop and rings the bell. A voice responds through the intercom with a heavy Slavic accent. This is MILICH.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Yes? Who is it?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Peter, this is Bill Harford. I apologize for disturbing you at this late hour but I need your help.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Who is it that you want?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh! I . .. I'm very sorry, I'm looking for Peter Grenning, the owner of Rainbow Fashions.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: What's your name?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: My name is Bill Harford. I'm Mr Grenning's doctor.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: You are Grenning's doctor?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: OK. Just a moment.

div.stage: BILL looks through the plate glass and sees a door open inside. From it a man appears and walks towards BILL.
The man is middle-aged, has a beard and long hair and wears a dressing gown. This is MILICH.
MILICHJ talks to BILL who stands on the steps outside the locked door.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: You are looking for Peter Grenning?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: He moved to Chicago - over a year ago.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: He moved to Chicago? Oh, I wasn't aware of that. Are you the present owner of Rainbow Fashions?

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, first of all, please let me apologize once again for disturbing you at this hour, Mr umm? ...

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Milich.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Mr Milich. Just to let you know that I really am Dr Harford, this is my New York State Medical Board Card.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: OK, so you are Dr Harford and if I see Peter I tell him you were looking for him.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh, no, no! Wait, please, please. Listen, the reason that I came here tonight was u.mm ... basically the reason is, is that I need a costume. And I'd be happy to pay you a hundred dollars over the rental price for the inconvenience.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: A hundred dollars?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: I don't think so.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, erh, OK. How about two hundred dollars?

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Two hundred dollars over the rental price?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: OK.

div.stage: MILICH opens the door, lets BILL in, then closes it behind them.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Come in.

div.stage: MILICH disables the burglar alarm system.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Can't be too careful these days, hmm.
Please.

div.stage: MILICH leads BILL through the shop to a counter. He switches on a lamp.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Is it any special costume you are looking for?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, umm ... I need a tux, a cloak with a hood, and a mask.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: A cloak with a hood and a mask?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: OK. I think we find something for you. Follow me, please.

div.stage: MILICH leads BILL into another room of the shop.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Looks like alive, huh?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, it's wonderful.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Come. So, what colour cloak?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Umm . ...

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Black,brown,red?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Black.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Are you sure the good doctor wouldn't like something more colourful?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I don't think so.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Clowns? Officers? Pirates?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, just the tux, the black cloak ....

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: With a hood and the mask.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: OK. May I take your coat?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

div.stage: BILL takes his coat and gives it to MILICH.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: You are medicine doctor, yes?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Oh, look, doctor. I have some problem with my hair, you know?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Your hair?

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: It's starting to fall down, too fast. I lost in two weeks a lot of hair, mostly here. Look at this, here.

div.stage: MILICH bends over to show his balding patch. BILL quickly examines it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh, yes.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: You see?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: And?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm afraid this really isn't my field.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: What, you can't help me?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, you should see a trichologist -it's a hair specialist ... Mr Milich. I've obviously left things a bit late tonight, so if you don't mind....

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: OK, OK. I'm in hurry too, doctor. To get back to bed.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I understand.

div.stage: MILICH casts BILL's overcoat aside and goes to a rail of hooded cloaks.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: So, black cloak?

div.stage: Suddenly, MILICH stops and turns to BILL.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Did you hear something? What is it?

div.stage: MILICH walks towards a room behind a glass wall at the back of the shop. He peers through the glass into the darkness to try to see where the noise came from.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: What is it?

div.stage: MILICH goes into the room through a door and switches on a light. He looks down to a low table laden with the remains of take-away meals. MILICH picks up a girl's slip and suddenly hears a sound behind him. He pulls aside a robe hanging on the wall to reveal a JAPANESE MAN in underpants and fright wig who sneezes. MILICH angrily grabs the wig and explodes in anger.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: What is this? What on earth is going on here?

sp.speaker: JAPANESE MAN 1
sp.p: Oh, Milich! I can explain everything. MILICH notices something behind the sofa. He attacks it with the wig in his hand and up jumps a young girl dressed only in a bra and panties. This is MILICH's DAUGHTER.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: You! What are you doing here? I'll kill you! I promise I'll kill you!

div.stage: Another JAPANESE MAN in a wig and covering his "modesty" with a cloth pops up from behind the sofa. MILICH grabs his wig and attacks him with it.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: And you, have you no sense of decency!? Gentlemen, have you no sense of decency!?

div.stage: The DAUGHTER grabs a shawl to cover herself.

sp.speaker: JAPANESE MAN 1
sp.p: Milich, are you crazy? We were invited here by the young lady.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Young lady? This is my daughter! Couldn't you see she's a child? You will have to explain to police.

sp.speaker: JAPANESE MAN 1
sp.p: To the police?

div.stage: MILICH makes for his DAUGHTER but she's off around the sofa. MILICH tries to catch her but she evades him. She runs into the shop and stands behind BILL who cannot understand what's going on.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: You little whore! I'll kill you for this! I promise, I'll kill you! ... I'll kill you!
Hold on to that girl for me, please.

div.stage: BILL looks at the DAUGHTER as she smiles up at him.

sp.speaker: JAPANESE
sp.p: Milich, this is preposterous. The young lady invited us here.

div.stage: MILICH angrily throws some clothing at the two cowering JAPANESE MEN.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Couldn't you see? She's ... deranged!
Doctor, I'm sorry to keep you waiting.
Gentlemen, this is now police matter. You will please stay here until I return.

div.stage: MILICH leaves the room and locks the door behind him, trapping the men inside.

sp.speaker: JAPANESE MAN 1
sp.p: Milich, what are you doing? Let us out of here.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: I'm afraid that's out of the question.
Doctor, sorry, what colour did you say?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Umm.... I

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Black?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Black.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Gentlemen, please . .. have the goodness to be quiet for the moment. Couldn't you see I try to serve my customer?
Sorry.
And you, little whore, go to bed at once, you depraved creature! I'll deal with you as soon as I serve this gentlemen.

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: You should have a cloak lined with ermine.

div.stage: The DAUGHTER slowly leaves the room, giving BILL a suggestive look as she goes. BILL looks at her perplexed.
A taxi speeds over the bridge.
BILL sits in the cab alone with his churning thoughts.
BILL's relentless fantasy returns as he imagines the NAVAL OFFICER and his wife making love.
BILL closes his eyes as if to shut out the thought of his wife with another man.
BILL's view from the cab as it swings off the bridge and onto a link road which will take it through the suburbs and out to the country.
The taxi drives through the suburbs. Festive illuminations strung across the road proclaim "HAPPY HOLIDAY."
The cab proceeds down a tree-lined country road.
BILL looks out to see where he is.

BILL's POV: the entry gates of a large country house can be seen through the trees to the right. Two men in dark coats are waiting in front of them. A sign shows the name of the house as "Somerton." The two men watch the cab closely.
The taxi slows to a halt.
The TAXI DRIVER switches on his light and BILL opens his wallet.

sp.speaker: CAB DRIVER
sp.p: OK. That's seventy-four fifty.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Seventy-four fifty, all right. There's eighty. I promised you fifty bucks over the meter, right? I'll make that a hundred ... if you wait for me.

div.stage: BILL holds up a $100 bill and tears it in half.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: So, let the meter run. I'll give you the other half, plus the meter, when I get back. OK?

sp.speaker: CAB DRIVER
sp.p: How long you gonna be?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I dunno, maybe an hour or more, but maybe only ten minutes. I'll leave my stuff here in the back. OK?

sp.speaker: CAB DRIVER
sp.p: OK.

div.stage: The TAXI DRIVER takes one half of the $100 note and BILL gets out of the cab.
BILL closes the cab door and slowly walks towards the two GATEMEN.

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: Good evening, sir.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good evening.

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: Can we be of any help?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, I suppose you'd like the password?

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: If you like, sir.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fidelio.

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: Thank you, sir. We'll run you up to the house. The GATEMAN gestures to a vehicle on the other side of the gates.

div.stage: A vast country house set amidst its own grounds. Limousines of all descriptions are lined up each side of the driveway. The vehicle ferrying BILL drives up and stops. BILL steps out and then walks up to the front door which is opened for him. BILL enters the house.
BILL walks in and is approached by a MASKED BUTLER. The sound of strange music can be heard in the background.

sp.speaker: MASKED BUTLER
sp.p: Good evening, sir.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good evening.

sp.speaker: MASKED BUTLER
sp.p: Password, sir.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fidelio.

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

div.stage: The MASKED BUTLER takes BILL's coat. Underneath BILL is wearing a hooded cloak. BILL then puts his mask on and pulls the hood over his head as he walks towards another door which is opened for him by a MASKED MAN. BILL enters.

BILL comes in through the door and walks slowly across the ante-room. A STEWARD, also masked, elegantly gestures him through heavy velvet drapes into a vast hall its walls, ceilings, balconies and columns all finely carved in white marble. The hall is crowded with people dressed similarly to BILL: black hooded cloaks and fullfaced Venetian Carnival-style masks of every conceivable design and colour. BILL sees a brightly lit circle of kneeling figures. In the centre is a figure wearing a red cloak who is conducting a strange ritual (this is RED CLOAK). He is waving an incense burner in one hand while holding a staff in the other.

At the far end of the hall BILL sees NICK heavily blindfolded and dressed in a white tuxedo. NICK is sitting at an array of keyboards producing eerie music that resonates through the hall and up to the marble balconies and galleries where gather cloaked and masked spectators.

RED CLOAK now walks slowly around the circle of figures and then moves to the centre. He bows deeply and the kneeling figures prostrate themselves before him. From a column furthest away from the spectacle BILL watches as RED CLOAK bangs his staff on the red carpet, a command that returns the figures to their kneeling positions. Then he moves slowly around the circle swinging the incense burner before moving back to the centre and banging the staff again which causes the figures to rise to their feet.

RED CLOAK bangs the staff on the carpet a further time: the figures unclasp the hooks of their cloaks and let them fall off their shoulders to the floor. The figures are now revealed to be beautiful young women, naked except for their masks and G-strings.

As RED CLOAK turns on the spot one of the women leans to her right to lightly embrace the woman next to her. She places a kiss on her lips. The kissed woman now leans to her right and repeats the act 'With the next woman, the kiss now being ''passed" around the circle.

While BILL tries to fathom what is happening two figures on a balcony opposite seem to be taking a more than passing interest in him. They continue staring at BILL until he slowly becomes aware of them. One of the figures wears a tricom mask while the other hides behind an androgynous mask. There is a sinister air to both of them. The man in the tricom mask bows to BILL, seemingly in recognition. BILL, uncertain at first, returns the bow. Then his attention is drawn back to the women in the circle.

RED CLOAK, with a rap of his staff on the floor, commands a woman to her feet. The woman bows to RED CLOAK who then bestows a "blessing" upon her. She then leaves the circle and approaches a man in the surrounding crowd. She leans forward to "kiss" the man, their masked lips touching, before leading him off out of the hall.
BILL watches as the procedure is repeated with the "blessed" women apparently choosing men at random from the spectators.

RED CLOAK has now reached a woman in the circle who wears a mask more alluring than the others, a beautiful design with black feathered plumes arising above her head (this is MYSTERIOUS WOMAN). After receiving the "blessing" the MYSTERIOUS WOMAN turns and walks straight to BILL.
She gently places her hand on his shoulder as she leans forward to "kiss" him. Then she leads BILL by the hand out of the hall.

The MYSTERIOUS WOMAN leads BILL down a red carpeted corridor which, like the hall, has walls of carved marble. On these walls are large mirrors which reflect the procession of almost-naked women leading the masked men away.

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: I'm not sure what you think you're doing, but you don't belong here.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm sorry, but I think you've mistaken me for someone else.

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: Please don't be foolish. You must go now.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: It doesn't matter who I am. You're in great danger. And you must get away while there is still a chance.

div.stage: An OMINOUS MAN in a large, almost over-sized mask, suddenly appears and takes the MYSTERIOUS WOMAN's hand.

sp.speaker: OMINOUS MAN
sp.p: Would you be so good as to excuse us for a moment? The OMINOUS MAN leads the MYSTERIOUS WOMAN away up a marble staircase. She looks back at BILL who is left wondering what is going on in the house.

div.stage: BILL follows a couple into a large hall that also has walls of carved marble. There are many doors and archways leading off.

A beautiful naked young woman is astride a man on his back. They are fucking and oblivious to the spectators crowded all around them. At the end of the room a naked man eases a woman in an elegant dress on to a polished table. He begins fucking her, unaware of BILL who passes closely by.
BILL enters the room. On a long table two naked women in a "sixty-nine" position simulate mutual cunnilingus.

Three other women sit on stools upon the table slowly and sensuously caressing each other's bodies. Gathered around the table are masked voyeurs enjoying the spectacle. BILL continues through the house.
BILL enters the ante-room. The focus of the crowd's attention is a naked woman, her hands held down by a masked woman in a red dress, who is being fucked from behind by a naked man.
BILL walks through and into a sumptuous library with oak paneled walls and bookcases full of leather bound volumes.
A roaring fire illuminates the bizarre scene of a masked man in formal evening dress on his hands and knees while on his back is a naked woman being fucked by another man in a Pan-like mask.

BILL joins the other onlookers. Then the man in the tricom mask enters the room accompanied by a naked YOUNG WOMAN. They stop and upon a signal from the man the YOUNG WOMAN walks up to BILL and stands next to him.

sp.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
sp.p: Have you been enjoying yourself?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I've had a very interesting look around.

sp.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
sp.p: Do you want to go somewhere a little more private?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Private? That might be a good idea.

div.stage: Suddenly, the MYSTERIOUS WOMAN in the beautiful feathered mask walks up to BILL and interrupts the conversation.

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: Oh, there you are! I've been looking all over for you. Where did you go?
May I borrow him for just a few minutes? I promise to bring him right back.

div.stage: The MYSTERIOUS WOMAN takes BILL by the hand and leads him out of the library.
The MYSTERIOUS WOMAN looks around her to make sure no one is about and then takes BILL across the hall.

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: I don't think you realize the danger you're in now. You can't fool them for much longer. You've got to get away before it's too late.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why are you telling me this?

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: It doesn't matter.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: You don't want to know, but you must go now.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Will you come with me?

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: That's impossible.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: Because it would cost me my life and possibly yours.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Let me see your face.

div.stage: BILL attempts to remove her mask but she holds tight.

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: No!

div.stage: She finally pushes his hands away and then leaves quickly.

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: Go!

div.stage: BILL looks towards her but before he can do anything a TALL BUTLER arrives. He too is masked.

sp.speaker: TALL BUTLER
sp.p: Excuse me, sir. Are you the gentleman with the taxi waiting for you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: TALL BUTLER
sp.p: Your driver's at the front door and would urgently like a word with you.

div.stage: He gestures BILL to follow him and they leave the room.
Couples dance, some naked, some in evening dress, as NICK Nightingale, still blindfolded, is led through the room and away down a corridor.

The TALL BUTLER escorts BILL down the same corridor along which the MYSTERIOUS WOMAN had earlier led BILL. As they reach the door of the white marble hall where BILL had witnessed the opening ritual, they stop. There, in the middle of the red carpet, sits RED CLOAK on a throne with acolytes in purple robes standing either side of him. They are surrounded by a circle of many people in black cloaks and masks. RED CLOAK beckons BILL to him.

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: Please come forward.

div.stage: As BILL enters the gap in the circle, the men in black cloaks close rank, cutting off any way of escape.

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: May I have the password, please?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fidelio.

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: That's right, sir. That is the password for admittance ... but may I ask what is the password for the house?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: The password for the house?

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm sorry I ... I ... I seem to have forgotten it.

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: That's unfortunate, because here it doesn't matter whether you have forgotten it or if you never knew it. You will kindly remove your mask.
Now get undressed.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Get undressed?

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: Remove your clothes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Gentlemen, please ....

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: Remove your clothes, or would you like us to do it for you? Suddenly, there is a shout from the balcony behind BILL.

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: Stop! Let him go. Take me, I am ready to redeem him.

div.stage: There is a gasp of surprise from the crowd. RED CLOAK gets to his feet.

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: You are ready to redeem him?

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: Yes.

div.stage: Another gasp of surprise from the crowd.

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: Are you sure you understand what you are taking upon yourself in doing this?

sp.speaker: MYSTERIOUS WOMAN
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: Very well. You are free, but I warn you if you make any further inquires or if you say a single word to anyone about what you have seen, there will be the most dire consequences for you and your family. Do you understand?

div.stage: BILL slowly nods his understanding and looks up to the MYSTERIOUS WOMAN on the balcony. The BIRD MASK MAN then takes her away.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What .. . what is going to happen to that woman?

sp.speaker: RED CLOAK
sp.p: No one can change her fate now. When a promise has been made here, there is no turning back. Go!

div.stage: The front door of the apartment opens and BILL comes in carrying a bag with his costume. He quietly shuts and locks the front door. He walks down the hallway and looks in at HELENA's room. She lies fast asleep. BILL turns away and walks on down through the living room, taking off his coat as he does, and into his study. He unlocks a cupboard and hides the bag with his costume there.

BILL walks into the bedroom to find ALICE asleep but munnuring in a dream. He sits on the side of the bed, and ALICE's noises tum to laughing. As the laugh becomes almost hysterical BILL gently touches her. She awakes with a "start" and is a little distressed.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Alice ... Alice ... OK. It's OK. I'm sorry, I'm sorry I woke you up but I thought you were having a nightmare.

div.stage: BILL starts to take off his shoes as ALICE tries to calm down.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, God ... I just had such a horrible dream. What time is it?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Er, a little after four.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Did you just get home?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, it took longer ... longer than I thought.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You must be exhausted. Come on, lie down, lie down.

div.stage: ALICE, still slightly upset, reaches out to him and pulls BILL down next to her.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What were you dreaming?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: It's just a ... just these weird things.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh . . . so weird.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Tell me.

div.stage: ALICE sits up, trying to recapture her dream.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: We ... we were ... we were in a deserted city and ... and our clothes were gone. We were naked, and ... and I was terrified, and I ... I felt ashamed. Oh, God! And ... and I was angry because I felt it was your fa ult. You ... you rushed away to try and find our clothes for us. As soon as you were gone it was completely clifferent. I ... I felt wonderful. Then I was lying in a .. . in a beautiful garden, stretched out naked in the sunlight, and a man walked out of the woods, he was ... he was the man from the hotel, the one I told you about ... the naval officer. He ... he stared at me and then he just laughed ... he just laughed at me.

div.stage: ALICE lies down again, burying her face in her pillow.
BILL sits up and looks at her crying into the pillow.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's not the end, is it?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why don't you tell me the rest of it?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: It's ... it's too awful.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's only a dream.

div.stage: ALICE gets close to BILL and envelopes him in her arms while summoning the courage to continue the story.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: He ... he was kissing me, and then ... then we were making love. Then there were all these other people around us ... hundreds of them, everywhere. Everyone was fucking, and then I ... I was fucking other men, so many ... I don't know how many I was with. And I knew you could see me in the arms of all these men, just fucking all these men, and I ... I wanted to make fun of you, to laugh in your face. And so I laughed as loud as I could. And that must have been when you woke me up.

div.stage: She weeps and caresses BILL who is perplexed and sits not knowing what to feel about what she has told him.
The following morning. A street full of traffic. Crowds.
A taxi pulls up and BILL gets out. He is carrying the bag with his costume from the night before. He walks up to the Cafe Sonata and sees the entrance grill closed and locked.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Shit....

div.stage: He wonders what to do. He looks around and sees that Gillespie's Coffee Shop next door is open. He goes inside.
BILL walks in and finds a seat at the counter. An attractive WAITRESS behind the counter greets him.

sp.speaker: WAITRESS
sp.p: Hi!

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hi. I'll just have a cup of coffee, please. She pours BILL a cup.

sp.speaker: WAITRESS
sp.p: Anything else?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, thank you.

div.stage: The WAITRESS writes a check and lays it in front of him.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Excuse me, would you happen to know when they get in next door at the Sonata Cafe?

sp.speaker: WAITRESS
sp.p: I think there's usually someone in the office round two or three.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Round two or three. Umm . . . I, erh . . . I don't suppose, by any chance, you know Nick Nightingale? He's playing piano over there right now?

sp.speaker: WAITRESS
sp.p: Nick Nightingale? Sure, he comes in here.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Look ... look maybe you can help me, because. it's very important that I get in touch with him this morning.. Do you know where he's staying?

sp.speaker: WAITRESS
sp.p: Well ... I, I don't know whether he would want me to give out his address.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's OK, I'm a doctor. I'm . .. I'm actually a very old friend of his.

div.stage: BILL shows her his State Medical Board card.

sp.speaker: WAITRESS
sp.p: Well, doctor, umm . . . he'll be playing there tonight. Can it wait until then?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Listen, to be perfectly honest, erh ... it's a medical matter, some tests. And I know he'll wanna know about them as soon as possible.

div.stage: The morning traffic is in full flow. The streets crowded with pedestrians. BILL, carrying his bag, walks up the street and comes to the Hotel Jason. He goes in.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Excuse me.

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Hi! How can I help you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Can you please ring Mr. Nightingale's room for me? Nick Nightingale.

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: I'm sorry, sir. Mr. Nightingale has already checked out.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: He checked out?

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Er .. . did he leave a forwarding address?

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: No, I'm afraid not, no.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: When did he check out?

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Umm ... about five o'clock this morning.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Five o'clock this morning?

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's a pretty early check out, isn't it?

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: It is a little on the early side, yeah.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Look ... did you notice anything, I dunno, unusual about him when he left?

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Unusual? Hey! You're not Five O , are you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, I'm an old friend of his.

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Really?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm a doctor.

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Oh.

div.stage: BILL shows him his State Medical Board Card. The CLERK starts getting very friendly.

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Well, umm ... Bill?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sure.

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: It's funny you should ask that question, Bill, because actually there was something a little strange about the way Mr. Nightingale left, yes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Really, what? What was that?

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Well ... he came in this morning about fourthirty a.m. with two men. Big guys. I mean, they were very well dressed and very well spoken but they weren't the kind of people you'd like to fool around with . . . if you know what I mean. Anyway, I noticed Mr. Nightingale had a bruise on his cheek and umm ... to be perlectly honest, I also thought he looked a little scared.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Scared?

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Yes, yes. He . . . he said he wanted to check out and then he went upstairs to his room with one of the men and the other guy stayed down in the lobby and settled his bill. And then, when they came back down, Mr. Nightingale tried to pass me an envelope but they saw it and and took it away and said that any mail or messages for him would be collected by someone properly authorized to do so. And then they just took him off in a car.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Do you have any idea where they went?

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: No, not a clue.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Um . .. well, anyway . . . I certainly .. . I certainly appreciate your help.

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Oh! Anytime, Bill. Bye!

div.stage: BILL leaves the Hotel Jason.
A taxi pulls up outside RAINBOW FASHIONS where BILL had hired the costume the night before. BILL gets out the cab with his bag and ascends the stoop.
BILL walks to the counter and puts the bag on it.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Oh, the good doctor.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Mr Milich.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Was your outfit the success?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, it was. Thank you.

div.stage: MILICH starts to take the costume out of the bag.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Good, good.
Tuxedo, cloak, shoes, erh... . I think you forgot the mask.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's not there?

div.stage: BILL, troubled, picks through the clothes on the counter.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: No, no, no. Maybe you left it at the party?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Er ... I don't think so. I must have lost it, Can you just put it on the bill, please?

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Sure.

div.stage: MILICH opens the till and takes out the receipt from the night before.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Here we are. That was one hundred fifty for the rental, two hundred you said for my trouble, twenty five for the mask - sorry. That's ... three hundred and seventy-five.

div.stage: Then the door at the end of the shop opens and the DAUGHTER appears who BILL saw with the JAPANESE MEN. She has only her bra and panties on with a flimsy kimono.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Yes, dear ... come, come.

div.stage: The DAUGHTER walks to the counter and stands next to MILICH.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Would you like to say hello to Dr Harford?

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Hello!

div.stage: She offers her hand to BILL and they shake.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hello.

div.stage: Then the JAPANESE MEN appear through the door, both smartly dressed. They hesitate on seeing BILL and then they slowly walk up to MILICH and his DAUGHTER.

sp.speaker: JAPANESE MAN 1
sp.p: Thank you, Mr Milich. I'll call you soon. Bye-bye.

div.stage: They take their leave, one of them blowing a kiss to the DAUGHTER.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Goodbye, gentlemen. Merry Christmas and happy new year!
Well, Dr Harlord, there is your receipt. I'm tearing up your deposits, and thanks for the business.
