div.stage: While MILICH does this BILL looks at the DAUGHTER who returns a knowing look. BILL is shocked by what he has seen.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Mr Milich, last night . . . you were going to call the police.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: Well . .. things change. We have come to another arrangement. And, by the way, if the good doctor himself should ever want anything again - anything at all. . . .

div.stage: MILICH puts his arm around his DAUGHTER's shoul ders. BILL sees the fragile, china doll-like face of the girl.

sp.speaker: MILICH
sp.p: It needn't be a costume ...

div.stage: BILL is left speechless at this invitation.
A busy avenue with office blocks in mid-town Manhattan.
BILL, in his white doctor's coat, sits deep in thought.
BILL continues to brood over the fantasy ofALICE making love with the NAVAL OFFICER.
BILL, still wrapped up in his thoughts, is interrupted by a knock at the door.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Come in.

div.stage: LISA comes in with a "take-away" food bag and coffee.

sp.speaker: LISA
sp.p: Tuna salad and black coffee.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thanks. Listen, how's my afternoon looking?

sp.speaker: LISA
sp.p: I think it's just Mrs Akerly at two-thirty and Mrs Kominski at four.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, look, something' s come up and I'm not going to be able to see them. Please ask Dr Miller if he can fit them in, otherwise just apologize and make new appointments.

sp.speaker: LISA
sp.p: Sure.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And please, call the garage and have them get my car out in half an hour.

sp.speaker: LISA
sp.p: No problem.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: OK?

sp.speaker: LISA
sp.p: Sure.

div.stage: BILL's Range Rover speeds over the bridge.
BILL continues driving over the bridge.
BILL's Range Rover on its way through the suburbs.

BILL's Range Rover slows down on a road lined with fir trees. It turns into the gateway of "Somerton" the house where the masked ball had been held the night before, and comes to a halt to the fore of the gates. Nobody is about.

BILL gets out of the Range Rover and slowly walks to the closed gates. He looks up and sees a surveillance camera tracking him. He is wondering what to do when he sees a limousine coming down the driveway towards him. It comes to a stop the other side of the gates.
An ELDERLY MAN, smartly dressed, gets out of the car and walks up to the gates while keeping a steady eye on BILL. He takes a letter from his inside pocket and pushes it through the gate.
BILL approaches the ELDERLY MAN and takes the letter. Without saying a word, the man tums, goes back to the car and is driven away.

BILL looks at the envelope and sees "DR. WILLIAM HARFORD" typed on it. He opens it and takes out a sheet of paper. Written on it is a warning to him: Give up your inquiries which are completely useless, and consider these words a second wanting. We hope, for your own good, that this will be sufficient.
BILL thinks long and hard about this warning and what it implies. He turns away from the gates to go back to his car.
Night time traffic. Illuminations. People walking about.
BILL comes in through the front door and closes it. He is wearing an overcoat and canying a case. He walks down the corridor.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Hi.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Hi, daddy!

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hi! Any calls for me?

div.stage: BILL takes his coat off and drops it over a chair in the hallway. He continues into the dining room where he sees ALICE sitting with HELENA doing some homework.
ALICE seems pleased to see him. BILL kisses ALICE on the head. and strokes HELENA's hair.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Dr Sanders and, erh ... Mrs Shapiro.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Hi, daddy!

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hey . ...

div.stage: HELENA proudly shows him her schoolbook.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Look, I got all these right.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You got all those right?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Every single one of them?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Ah-hah ....

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's good

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You hungry?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Er ... sort of.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Want to eat at seven?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Ooh! Seven. Listen, can we make that a little earlier because I have some appointments at the office?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You have to go out again, tonight?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Mmm, afraid so.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Daddy, am I gonna get a puppy for Christmas?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, we'll ... we'll see about that OK?

div.stage: BILL walks into the kitchen, opens the fridge and takes out a drink.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: He could be a watchdog?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: We'll see.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Come on, baby, let's finish this off. All right, we have Joe and Joe has two dollars fifty, Mike has one dollar and seventy-five cents. Joe has bow much more money than Mike?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: One hundred and seventy-five.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: So, is it going to be a subtraction or addition?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Hmmm . .. how much more means,that it would be an subtraction, wouldn't it?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yeah, so you are going to be taking, right ...

div.stage: As ALICE helps HELENA with her homework BILL watches from the kitchen ALICE's words from the night before come back to haunt him:

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: And there were all these other people. Hundreds of them everywhere, and everyone was fucking. And then I ... I was fucking other men, so many, I ... I don't know bow many I was with.

div.stage: While BILL can hear her voice in his head ALICE gives him a look full of love and affection. BILL responds with a forced smile.
The Christmas lights illuminate the area. At the end of the reception we see a door ajar and light coming through it.
BILL sits staring at the telephone.
The thought of ALICE making love with the NAVAL OFFICER invades BILL's mind again.
BILL, still staring at his phone, decides to act. He picks up the receiver and punches in a number.
The phone rings in the hallway. CARL walks down the corridor and picks up the receiver.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Hello? Hello? Hello?

div.stage: BILL is disappointed at heanng CARL's voice. He had been expecting MARION to answer.
CARL is still trying to get a response from the telephone.
BILL thinks for a moment, then puts the p"hone down. He is clearly troubled.
A taxi pulls up at the curbside outside DOMINO's apartment building in Greenwich Village. BILL gets out and pays his fare.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Keep the change. Merry Christmas.

div.stage: BILL is carrying a small cake-box. The cab drives off as BILL walks up the stoop to the front door. He stands aside to let a parcel-laden lady go by, then goes irz. through the front door.
A shabby lobby. BILL walks up to the apartment door. He rings the bell. A woman's voice is heard from the other side of the door. This is SALLY.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Who is it?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Domino?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: No, she's not in.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Er .. . are you expecting her back soon?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: No, I'm not.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: OK. I have something for her. Can I leave this with you?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Just a minute ....

div.stage: The door is unlocked and SALLY's face appears. BILL gives her the cake boxr

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Can I say who it's from?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, just tell her it's from Bill.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: You're Bill . .. the Bill? You're the doctor who was here last night?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, I suppose I am.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Domino said how nice you were to her.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Did she?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Uh-huh. Why don't you come in for a second?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sure.

div.stage: BILL enters the apartment.
SALLY closes and locks the door. She is very attractive, about DOMINO's age, and she signals to BILL to go into the kitchen. As he enters he stops and turns.
SALLY, who likes the look of him, puts the cake on the table and blatantly pushes herself up against him.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I'm Sally.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hello, Sally.

div.stage: BILL, taking offhis overcoat, is not reticent in returning the advance.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Hi.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: So, do you have any idea when you expect Domino back?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: No, I have no idea.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You have no idea? They are flirting heavily now.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: No. Well, to be perfectly honest, she ... she may not even be coming back.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: She may not even be coming back?

div.stage: Excited by their closeness, BILL starts to fondle SALLY's breast.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Well, umm , .. I, erh ....

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You, erh....

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I think some ... something that I should tell you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Really?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Yeah ... but I don't know.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You don't know? What is it?

div.stage: SALLY is very taken by the advance from BILL, but forces herself to talk.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I don't know whether to tell you this. Oh, well ... why don't you ... why don't you have a seat?
OK, let's sit down.

div.stage: They separate and sit at each end of the kitchen table. BILL laughs at SALLY's difficulty in saying what is on her mind.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Oh .. . I don't quite know how to say this.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You don't quite know how?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Well, considering that you were with Domino last night ...

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hmm....

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I think it would be only fair to you, to let you know that, umm .. . she got the results of a blood test this morning and, erh ... it was HIV positive.

div.stage: BILL is taken aback. He was not expecting news like this.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: HIV positive?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Yeah.

div.stage: BILL doesn't know what to say.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, I am very ... very sorry to hear that.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Yeah, I mean, it's absolutely devastating.

div.stage: Both of them sit there, lost for something to say. SALLY tries to snap out of it.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Listen, can I offer you anything? Cup of coffee maybe?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No thank you. I think erh . .. maybe I had better be going.

div.stage: It is deserted, but for a passing car, as we see BILL slowly walking down the street.

BILL, hands thrust deep in his pockets, becomes aware ofsomebody else walking behind him. He looks back and sees a figure keeping a distance on the opposite side of the street. BILL realizes he is being followed. This is the STALKER.
BILL turns a comer and checks behind him. He continues down the street and looks back.
The STALKER, though keeping his distance, has now crossed to BILL's side of the stree·t. He's a heavy set guy with a shaved head.
BILL, now worried, tries to hail a cab, but none stpp. Then he sees a ta.xi. pull up and someone gets out. BILL runs across to grab the cab and starts to open the door.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Taxi.

sp.speaker: DRIVER
sp.p: Off duty.

div.stage: The cab pulls away, leaving BILL at the curbside.

BILL tries to see if the STALKER is still following him and then decia,es to continue walking. As he reaches a newspaper kiosk he sees the STALKER come round the comer and stop. BILL stops too and looks at him for some time while wondering what will happen next.

BILL then picks up a copy of the New York Post and throws some change down. The STALKER crosses the street, all the time keeping a steady watch on BILL. Then he stops and BILL waits. Finally, after a stand-off, the STALKER walks away leaving BILL feeling very anxious.
BILL turns and walks down the street. He sees Sharkey's Cafe and welcomes the security the company of other people will afford him.
BILL walks up the stairs and into the cafe.
BILL enters. Mozart's Requiem is playing and the place is full of people. He goes to the counter and a friendly waitress looks up.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'll just have a cappuccino, please.

sp.speaker: WAITRESS
sp.p: I'll bring it over to you.

div.stage: BILL sees a table at the other end of the room and goes across to it. He sits down and opens the New York Post and glances agitatedly out of the cafe windows. Suddenly, something in the paper catches his eye: a headline which reads, EX-BEAUTY QUEEN IN HOTEL DRUGS OVERDOSE. He reads the article in dread of what it seems to be revealing.
A busy Manhattan general hospital: ambulances, cars, staff and public.
Through the revolving glass doors, we see a cab pull up outside. BILL gets out and walks through the revolving door and up to the reception desk.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good evening.

sp.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
sp.p: Good evening.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm Dr Harford. One of my patients was admitted earlier this morning, a Miss Amanda Curran. Could you please give me her room number?

sp.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
sp.p: Certainly. Her name again?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Curran. Amanda Curran.

div.stage: The RECEPTIONIST checks the spelling as she enters the name on the computer.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
sp.p: Miss Amanda Curran?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
sp.p: I'm sorry, doctor, Miss Curran died this afternoon.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: She died this afternoon?

sp.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
sp.p: Yes, at three-forty-five p.m. I'm sorry.

div.stage: BILL follows an ORDERLY down the corridor.
The ORDERLY leads BILL into the morgue and then walks over to a bank of refrigerated body drawers and pulls out a body on a tray. He steps back.
BILL stands looking at the corpse - we recognize her as the woman we saw at ZIEGLER's party, the one who had over-dosed in the bathroom, MANDY.

BILL leans closer to study her face. He moves around to her head. He leans forward, bringing his face close to hers, and closes his eyes. It's as if he were going to kiss her. He stops short and slowly pulls back until he is looking down at her face.
Despondently, BILL walks down the corridor. His mobile phone rings. He takes it out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hello? Yes, it's Dr Harford ... Tonight? ... No, no, no. That's OK. Just, please, tell him that. I'll be there in about twenty minutes ... OK?

div.stage: Lights burning in most rooms. Night traffic.
HARRIS, ZIEGLER's personal assistant, leads BILL down the corridor and across the hall. Not a word is spoken. They come to a door and HARRIS knocks on it.

A big, pine paneled room, lined with books and antique artifacts. In the middle of the room ZIEGLER is alone, playing shots on the billiard table. ZIEGLER hears the knock, puts the cue down and walks across the room to the door.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Come in.

div.stage: HARRIS opens the door, lets BILL in and closes the door immediately after.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Bill, I appreciate you coming.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sure.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Sorry to drag you over tonight. Let me have your coat.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, no. I ... I was out anyway, thank you.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: How about a drink?

div.stage: ZIEGLER gives BILL a friendly slap on the shoulder as he takes his coat.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Are you having one?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Sure.

div.stage: They walk over to the drinks table. ZIEGLER laying BILL's coat over an annchair.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: OK.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: What would you like?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Just a little scotch.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Good. How do you take it? Neat?

div.stage: ZIEGLER pours the drinks.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Please. That was a terrific party the other night. Alice and I had a wonderful time.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Well, good, good. It was great seeing you both. Cheers.

div.stage: They "clink" glasses and ZIEGLER leads BILL over to the billiard table.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Cheers. Were you playing?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: No. Just knocking a few balls around.

div.stage: They face each other across the table as BILL takes a drink.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Beautiful scotch.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: That's a twenty-five-year-old. I'll send you over a case.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, please.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Sure, why not?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No ... no!

sp.speaker: ZIBGLER
sp.p: You, erh ... do you feel like playing?

div.stage: ZIEGLER starts playing with a billiard ball. He looks particularly ill at ease.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No thanks .. . you go ahead. I'll watch.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: No, no, no, no, no, no. I ... I was just, erh .... Listen, Bill, the reason I asked you to come over, I, I ... I need to talk to you about something.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sure.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: It's a little bit awkward. And I have to be completely frank.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What kind of problem are you having?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: It isn't a medical problem.

div.stage: ZIEGLER slowly walks around the tabl.e towards BILL.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Actually, it concerns you, Bill ... I . .. I know what happened last night. And I know what's been going on since then. And I think youjust might . . . have the wrong idea about one or two things.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm sorry, Victor, I . . . what in the hell are you talking about?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Please, Bill, no games. I was there, at the house. I saw everything that went on. Bill, what the hell did you think you were doing?

div.stage: ZIEGLER picks up his glass and starts to pace the floor.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: I couldn't, I couldn't even begin to, to imagine how, how you had even heard about it, let alone got yourself through the door. And then I remembered seeing you with that ... that ... that prick piano player .. . Nick whatever-thefuck his name was at my party. It didn't take much to figure out the rest.

div.stage: BILL stares at the table in embarrassment.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It wasn't Nick's fault. It was mine.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Of course it was Nick's fault. If he hadn't m·e ntioned it to you in the first place, none of this would have happened. I recommended that little cocksucker to those people and he's made me look like a complete asshole.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Victor, what can I say? I had . . . absolutely no idea you were involved in any way.

div.stage: ZIEGLER leans on the table trying to gain composure.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: I know you didn't, Bill. But I also know that you ... you went to Nick's hotel this morning and talked to the desk clerk.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Because I had you followed.

div.stage: BILL "snorts" a short laugh in response.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You had me followed?

div.stage: Now it is ZIEGLER's turn to be embarrassed.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: I ... OK, OK! I'm sorry all right. I owe you an apology, I . .. this was for your own good, believe me. Now look, I know what the desk clerk told you but what he didn't tell you is that all they did was put Nick on a plane to Seattle. By now he's probably back with his family ... probably banging Mrs Nick.

div.stage: ZIEGLER's attempt to lighten the conversation falls flat with BILL.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: The clerk said he had a bruise on his face.

div.stage: ZIEGLER moves closer to BILL and sits on the table.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: OK, he had a bruise on his face. That's a hell of a lot less than he deserves. Listen, Bill. I don't think you realize what sort of trouble you were in last night.

div.stage: ZIEGLER gets off the table, picks up BILL's glass and walks to the drinks table.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: What do you think those people were? They weren't just ordinary people there. If I told you their names ... I'm not gonna tell you their names, but if I did, I don't think you'd sleep so well.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Was it the second password? Is that what gave me away?

div.stage: ZIEGLER pours more scotch for BILL and himself and puts BILL's glass on the billiard table. ZIEGLER then walks over to an armchair on the other side of the room.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Yes, finally. But not because you didn't know it ... it's because there was no second password.

div.stage: ZIEGLER sits down in the armchair.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Of course, it didn't help a whole lot ... those people arrive in limos and you showed up in a taxi. Or, that when they took your coat, they found the receipt from the rental house in your pocket, made out to you-know-who ....

div.stage: BILL moves away and turns his back on ZIEGLER. He feels very awkward.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: There was a ... there was a ... there was a woman there, who, erh ... tried to warn me.

sp.speaker: ZIBGLER
sp.p: I know....

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Do you know who she was?

div.stage: ZIEGLER gets up and goes near to where BILL stands with his back still turned. He puts his glass on the edge of the table.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Yes ... she was ... she was a hooker. Sorry, but that's what she was.

div.stage: BILL moves away, still with his back to ZIEGLER and sits in an armchair. He runs his hand through his hair, trying to figure everything out.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: A hooker?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Bill, suppose I told you that .. . that everything that happened to you there, the threats, the girls . .. warnings, the last minute interventions . .. suppose I said all of that was staged, that it was a kind of charade? That it was fake?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fake?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Yes, fake.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why would they do that?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Why? In plain words, to scare the living shit out of you. To keep you quiet about where you'd been and what you'd seen.

div.stage: BILL takes the article he tore out of the New York Post in Sharkey's Cafe and hands it to ZIEGLER who looks at it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Have you seen this?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Yes, I have. He folds it and gives it back to BILL.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I saw her body, in the morgue. Was she ... was she the woman at the party?

div.stage: ZIEGLER, hands in pockets, moves away to the billiard table.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Yes, she was.

div.stage: BILL, in an attempt to put everything together, gets up and walks away from ZIEGLER as if to put some distance between them.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Victor, the woman lying dead in the morgue was the woman at the party?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Yes.

div.stage: BILL, getting very upset, turns round on ZIEGLER.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, Victor, maybe I'm . .. missing something here. You called it a fake, charade. Do you mind telling me what kind of fucking charade ends with somebody turning up dead?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: OK, Bill. Let's ... let's ... let's . . . let's cut the bullshit, all right? You've been way out of your depth for the last twenty-four hours. You wanna know what kinda charade? I'll tell you exactly what kind. That whole play-acted "take me" phony sacrifice that you've been jerking yourself off with had absolutely nothing to do w ith her real death. Nothing happened to her after you left that party that hadn't happened to her before. She got her brains fucked out. Period.

When they took her home she was just fine and the rest of it's right there in the paper. She was a junky. She OD'd. There was nothing suspicious. Her door was locked from the inside. The police are happy. End of story.
Come on ... it was always just gonna be a matter of time with her. Remember, you told her so yourself? Remember the one with the great tits who OD'd in my bathroom?

div.stage: BILL hangs his head as he recollects that it was indeed what he'd told ZIEGLER and MANDY at the party after the "bathroom incident."
BILL slowly moves away as ZIEGLER, trying to mollify him, walks up behind him.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Listen, Bill. Nobody killed anybody. Someone died. It happens all the time. Life goes on. It always does until it doesn't.

div.stage: ZIEGLER lays his hands on BILL's shoulders in a friendly reassuring way.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: But you know that, don't you?

div.stage: The mask that BILL wore at the ball rests an a pillow bathed in moonlight. Next to it lies ALICE asleep.

The front door opens and a totally dejected BILL enters. He slowly walks down the hallway, takes off his over- coat and just dumps it on a chair. He walks across the living room towards the illuminated Christmas tree. He pauses to look at the tree then switches its lights off.

BILL takes off his jacket and hangs it over the back of a chair. Tired and exhausted he walks, dejectedly, into the kitchen, loosening his tie. He goes to the fridge and takes out a can of beer. Then he goes to the table, slumps down into a chair and starts to drink.

BILL quietly opens the bedroom door. To his dismay, he sees the mask on the pillow next to ALICE. BILL, emotionally wrecked, walks slowly towards the bed and sits down with tears in his eyes. Finally, he can restrain himself no longer, and breaks down into uncontrollable sobbing. ALICE wakes to see BILL's complete helplessness as he collapses and lays his head on her breast. She puts an ann around him as he sobs.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'll tell you everything. I'll tell you everything.

div.stage: Dawn has given way to early morning. ALICE, cigarette in hand, sits in tearful silence as she contemplates what BILL has told her. She looks at BILL who sits on the sofa opposite looking ashamed, humiliated, remorseful.
ALICE, trying to constrain her disappointment, remembers what they have to do this day.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Helena's gonna be up soon. She's uh ... she's expecting us to take her Christmas shopping today.

div.stage: BILL and ALICE walk together with HELENA who is trying to catch the soap bubbles floating in the air above her. Then HELENA run's off as BILL and ALICE follow, BILL glancing anxiously at ALICE as they go. They catch up with HELENA as she looks at a toy pram.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: That's nice.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: I could put Sabrina in here.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: It's really ... pretty.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: It's old fashioned.

div.stage: HELENA runs off again and when BILL and ALICE catch up with her, they see she has discovered a huge teddy bear.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: He's big.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: I hope Santa Claus gets me one of these for Christmas!

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You do?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Well, you're gonna have to wait and see.

div.stage: HELENA runs off again, and BILL and ALICE follow, each with everything to say but no way of saying it until BILL plucks up the courage to speak.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Alice . .. what do you think we should do?

div.stage: They stop and ALICE tries to gather her thoughts.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: What do I think we should do?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Look, Mommy.

div.stage: BILL and ALICE look at HELENA who holds up a fairy doll. They smile at her.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh ... what do I think? I dunno. I mean, maybe ...

div.stage: They move away into an aisle where ALICE stops and begins to explain her feelings. HELENA walks between them which brings ALICE to a halt.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Hey!

div.stage: When she thinks HELENA is out of earshot, ALICE continues, searching for words.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Maybe, I think, we should be grateful ... grateful that we've managed to survive through all of our adventures, whether they w ere real or only a dream.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Are you ... are you sure of that?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Am ... am I sure? Umm ... only ... only as sure as I am that the reality of one night, let alone that of a whole life time, can ever be the whole truth.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And no dream is ever just a dream.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Hmm . .. The important thing is we're awake now and hopefully for a long time to come.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Forever.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Forever?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Forever.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Let's ... let's not use that word, it frightens me. But I do love you and you know there is something very important we need to do as soon as possible?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Fuck.
